fields.description:
It is often the case that there are multiple build plans that make use of a shared resource in the testing environment, and that running these concurrently causes problems.

Bamboo needs a mechanism, such as a special kind of build requirement, that prevents such build plans from being run concurrently.
fields.summary: Mechanism to prevent builds that use a shared resource from running concurrently

fields.description:
It's difficult to be sure what's going on, because there's not much logging information, but when I execute a plan on a remote machine, the agent shutsdown on the remote machine.  I'm able to see:  "Exiting Bamboo Agent..." in the command window where I'm running the agent, but this is not logged.

There's this interesting message in the agent's startup log.

2008-03-31 10:19:27,947 INFO [Thread-3] [PerforceManager] Attempting to extract Perforce Executable
2008-03-31 10:19:27,947 INFO [Thread-3] [PerforceManager] Could not find system variable


I've checked and rechecked the agent's Perforce capability - that should be OK.  

There's a message/stack trace in the server log, when the plan starts to execute that might be related:

INFO   | jvm 1    | 2008/03/31 08:18:52 | 2008-03-31 08:18:52,750 ERROR [btpool0-3] [FiveOhOh] 500 Exception was thrown.


I've attached a .txt file with agent log up to the shutdown and what seems relevant from the server log at that time for more info.

Setup JDK 1.6 functional tests on Panda

fields.description:
Remove page numbers from titles of Bamboo documentation. Now that page ordering has been implemented in CAC, we no longer need to use page numbers in the titles to force ordering.

Having page numbers in the titles also complicates adding new pages (especially if the number goes into double digits) or reordering existing pages, as the excerpt macro does not refresh with the links.

Not a trivial task!
fields.summary: Remove page numbers from titles of Bamboo documentation

fields.description:
Henrik:
 I got Bamboo up and running behind Apache using mod_proxy  :-) 
I used the apache directives your referred me to, combining them with
a new context root for my our Bamboo installation.

What I did was:
Changed the context root in conf/wrapper.conf, changing
wrapper.app.parameter.4=/
to
wrapper.app.parameter.4=/bamboo

And then added the following to the apache httpd.conf.

ProxyRequests Off
ProxyPreserveHost On

<Proxy *>
    Order deny,allow
    Allow from all
</Proxy>

ProxyPass /bamboo http://localhost:8085/bamboo
ProxyPassReverse /bamboo http://localhost:8085/bamboo
<Location /bamboo>
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
</Location>


And in the end restarted both... It worked brilliantly...
It actually worked so well I got the time to set up an installation of Jira on the same machine, also proxied behind Apache :-)

Nicholas:
>>  While we don't have any specific documentation for this - no one has
>>  asked before - it is possible. The JIRA or Confluence documentation
>>  will provide a good starting point for configuring Bamboo in this
>>  manner.
>>
>>  I recommend you have a look at the Confluence documentation available
>>  here:
>>
>>         http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Using+Apache+with+mod_proxy
>>
>>  Thanks for the email Henrik, I look forward to hearing of your
>>  progress. If you have any queries don't hesitate to get in contact.
fields.summary: Document Bamboo & mod_proxy configuration

fields.description:
The display range filter is currently hard-coded to only 5 possible choices.

This should be configurable by at least the administrator (site wide) or by individual users.

The possible filters should also include possibilities such as "Since build #X" and/or "Since Feb 17 2008"... This would allow quickly viewing the progression of the current release cycle, sprint, quarter, or whatever particular teams may use.

fields.description:
Another CI build execution model, is to allow some time for additional changes to arrive in the repository before building to ensure that a developer has checked in all changes associated with the bug, feature, etc.  This can help reduce failures.

Having a configurable monitor to allow for repository "cool off"  would be a handy feature in Bamboo.  Something like:  Check for changes every 5 minutes (Bamboo obviously has this) - but then start a configurable countdown.   If no additional changes are found in the next 3 minutes, execute a build.   If changes are found, restart the countdown.  

I "think" CruiseControl offers this functionality.  Other commercial CI apps don't seem to offer this by default.
fields.summary: Allow for a repository "cool down" period before executing a build

fields.description:
We have a plan with a builder that has the "Working Sub Directory:" with the value of "foo" and a "Test Results Directory:"  with the value of "results/junit/xml/*.xml".  We are building it via a remote agent on an Ubuntu 7.10 box.  Every build fails with the following error message in the "Error Summary" area on the "Summary" tab:

    Could not find ant Junit test results in the /home/user/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/FAST/foo directory.

Even though it is supposed to be looking in the "results/junit/xml/*.xml" directory.  If I move the "results/junit/xml/*.xml" directory to the foo directory the build succeeds.

It looks like it is using the "Working Sub Directory" as the base for the "Test Results Directory".
fields.summary: The The Test Results Directory value is not used by the builder

fields.description:
It is possible to navigate to an artifact from the latest build using a URL of the form:

[base URL]/download/[project key]-[plan key]/artifacts/latest/[artifact name]

At present, this is implemented by generating a static HTML file containing a client-side refresh.

This has at least a couple of disadvantages:
# It does not work well with tools such as wget and curl, that do not make use of the client-side refresh; and
# [It breaks if an artifact is subsequently deleted|BAM-1743].

We should instead dynamically generate a [302 Found|http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-10.3.3] response.
fields.summary: Reimplement "latest" artifact URLs as 302 redirects, rather than client-side refreshes

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1- Run build on remote agent
2- restart remote agent within 2min while building
3- look at current activity screen of plan v dashboard (for agent)..

Fix:

We should track a start up time for every time an agent reports a heartbeat. If the start up time has changed - the agent has restarted and we should publish an agent restarted event to handle the scenario (similar to what happens when the heartbeatcheckerjob detects an agent has fully gone offline).
fields.summary: Remote agent restart can leave builds in a building state while the agent reports it is idle
Add dependencies tab, to the Create plan wizard to add dependencies while creating plan.

fields.description:
Normally, artifacts have a URL of the form:

[base URL]/download/[project key]-[plan key]/artifacts/build-[build number]/[artifact name]

But you can obtain a permanent URL that will always link to the most recent version of an artifact by replacing the second last section with "latest", so that it becomes:

[base URL]/download/[project key]-[plan key]/artifacts/latest/[artifact name]

We should document this feature.
fields.summary: Document the ability to link to the latest version of an artifact

fields.description:
From BSP-641
{code}
Bamboo cannot handle the CVS-Errormessages in the right way:

We have some Sourcecode generators during our ant builds. These generators also create some stubs, which are jsut generated one time and the developer has to implement them manually. After beginning the manual implementation, these files are checked in the CVS. Usually the check in of the model and the check in of the manual implementations happen in one step. Sometimes that is not possible.
At the build server bamboo creates now the stubs and puts them into the source-folder. Then the developer checks in the stubs at his own machine. At the next time Bamboo runs the plan, it wants to update that folder. But the CVS says (i.e.):

cvs update: move away src/de/xxx/xxx/common/components/clickandbuy/xxx.java; it is in the way
C src/de/xxx/xxx/common/components/xxxl.java

Bamboo recognizes the changed files but cannot get the history, because bamboo has just the wrong files... The Build should fail with the error message of the CVS...
{code}
fields.summary: Bamboo ignores CVS error messages and updates on wrong files, and reports "Update By Unknown" in the changes  tab

fields.description:
I would like an authentication mode where the appearance of the basic authentication username indicates that user is properly authenticated into this service.  We're using Apache + SSL + Tomcat + mod_jk + mod_auth_kerb to authenticate against an AD-based  Kerberos Domain Controller for other services, and we would like to delegate authentication for Bamboo to our current distributed authentication configuration as well.

os_authType=basic gets us most of the way there, but bamboo wants to test the Basic Authentication passcode against its own stored copy.  What we want is for the passcode to live in Active Directory, without requiring Bamboo to have login credentials to access Active Directory directly.

BTW, aside from the use of Kerberos, this feature would also be useful to organizations which are already using some kind of Basic Authentication within their web server to protect other assets, and who don't need Bamboo to maintain extra copies of the passcode.

Maybe said feature might be triggered by os_authType=basic_deferred ?
fields.summary: Basic Authentication

fields.description:
The bamboo integration with jira could be improved by allowing 2 urls for linking between the applications.

Our scenario is that bamboo and jira (actually all the atlassian products) are hosted as webapps in tomcat, but developer access to them is via apache which applies an authentication filter mandated by our infrastructure.  We have also created filters in front of the tomcat applications to manage users/groups in jira/bamboo based on the apache filter.

Since the actual tomcat instances should not be directly accessible to end users, it is impossible to integrate jira/bamboo using the existing plugins.

Ideally, when specifying the integration between the products, we should be able to provide 2 urls.

INTEGRATION URL:  the trusted application link url - used to do the backend integration.  (e.g. http://localhost:8085/)
ACCESS URL: the end-user url - used when displaying the links to the end user.    (e.g.  http://intranet/bamboo/)
fields.summary: Allow split between public facing url/internal url for bamboo/jira integration.

Test A fails says its failing since build 2 not build 1
fields.summary: Failing since build for a test reports the wrong result

fields.description: currently, build plan dependencies must be specified manually. it would be nice to have bamboo read the dependencies of maven projects to each other and allow to have build plan dependency managed by the maven dependency mechanism. However, this feature should not be 'forced', as sometimes it is unwanted to build all dependent projects.
fields.summary: have a better maven integration, e.g., build plan dependency extraction from the maven pom(s)

fields.description:
suppose i have a plan c, that i set to be built (plan dependency) after b, which is set to be built after a.
if c is on the build queue, and i add b to it, an alternative algorithm should now put b before c on the queue. 
currently, if my queue is c,b,a (c to be built first, so directly inverse the dependendency) it will cause bamboo to build in this order finally:
c, b, a, c (as when b finishes, c is added), b (as when a finishes, b is added), c (as when b finishes, c is added)
where the last three would have been unneccesary under the circumstance that the queue c,b,a would have existed before build of c had started. So in this worst case, bamboo currently builds twice as often as it would need to.
fields.summary: have a better build dependency queuing algorithm, or possibility to choose the queing type

fields.description:
From the perforce docs

"If you have any AltRoots: configured, your Perforce client program compares the current working directory against the main Root: first, and then against the alternate roots, and uses the first root that matches the current working directory as the workspace root for that command. If no roots match, the main workspace root is used."

That means that currently perforce will not be able to find any of the roots and will default to the main root.  If this main root doesn't exist it creates it within the current working directory (wherever bamboo is running from).

The only solution to this is to determine which root exists before hand and set the running directory to this.  This is relatively substantial change to the perforce back-end.

For now we not build unless the main root exists, to avoid the whole alt root problem.
fields.summary: Get Perforce Alternat Roots to Work

fields.description:
Artifacts storage has two options, move or copy.  

For some reason the local side of things was set to move as opposed to copy to accommodate some remote agent issue (performance problems??).  This however breaks the local artifact storage (it removes the artifacts from the source code directory).  

I have changes this back to copy rather than move for the moment.  We need to re look at this.
fields.summary: Artifacts copy problems with local/remote agents

fields.description: It'd be a nice feature to have build plans auto-save as drafts during the creation process. There are a number of steps to go through when creating a build plan and it can be a little frustrating when you're part way through but lack some information and have to stop. Either auto-save or some sort of 'save as draft' functionality would be cool. I'd imagine this working in a similar way to GMail when you're composing a new email.
fields.summary: Add auto-save feature for plans

fields.description:
It would be nice if Bamboo used the same mechanism as JIRA regarding the distribution. So instead of downloading a WAR file, you download a tar.gz file which you need to build yourself using a build.sh. I came across this when integrating Bamboo with crowd and I needed to open the war file myself and needed modify the contents of the war file.

The buildable distribution has the following advantages:

- It is clear what you changed in contrast to the original by using the edit-webapp feature
- You don't have to open and zip up the war file manually, which can be error phrone
- different atlassian products have same distribution
fields.summary: Make bamboo distribution based on same principal as JIRA

fields.description:
See https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-631

Currently Bamboo assumes that it can run the p4 users command without being logged in.  Because of this the user is not actually set before it runs the command, and, when it cant run the command, it must look to the system user for login which is often not set up.

A workaround solution is to have a line in your protect file for all users (e.g. list user * * //...) or create the system root user.

fields.description:
We changed perforce to set the source code directory to the plans build-dir folder as opposed to using the root defined in perforce.

The reasons for this change are:

The reason the changes were made initially was to make it easier for you to run distributed builds.  The benefit of this is that a single plan can be run on different remote agents and different machines using the one client file.  You don't have to worry about ensuring that the workspace root exists exactly the same on all of these boxes, Bamboo will look after it all for you. It also mean that the build data is stored in your bamboo home rather than elsewhere on the system (where there may be permissioning issues). There were also some issues with caching the source repository that we were trying to resolve.

The problem is that there now needs to be one client per plan in case they build at the same time and alter the dir.  Some customers have expressed that this is not a good idea.

see http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=24094

Alternatives:

* Switch it back to the way it was (just using perforce's definition)
* Provide a toggle - the user can pick the old way or the new way

Concerns

* The caching source dir is not necessarily needed at this point in time as the build process has changed
* What are the consequences if it ever fails to get the client root
* Can only set 2 alternate roots - (this functionality hasn't been tested yet either)
* If there is the option the user will have to ensure that he doesn't have 1 client set to manage on one plan and not manage on another
fields.summary: Resolve perforce source directory issue

fields.description:
From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257276266#257276266 -
{quote}Bamboo 2.0 Beta4 does not seem to accept a new P4 Workspace name once the build plan is created. I have tried to enter a new exisiting workspace name when creating a new build plan as well as when updating an existing one and I get an error saying "Client was not found on the perforce server". It might work if I restart the Bamboo server but only the first time. Is this a known issue with the Beta4 build? Is there a work around for this?{quote}

fields.description:
We have a few plans that are CVS-based, set to build whenever the repository changes, with a polling frequency of 60.  For whatever reason, these builds aren't locating changes anymore.  After the import, the initial build-dir directories were empty, so I manually clicked 'Start Build' on each plan, and the code was checked out and the plan ran.  Now it seems to not detect any more changes.  

A lot of things like this:

2008-03-11 13:10:33,077 INFO [pool-13-thread-1] [InitialBuildListener] Changed detection request for LW-COMPILE ignored. Plan is currently busy (may already be building)

.. are printed in the logs.  No changes are found when CVS is polled.  There are lingering lockfiles left on the CVS server that get re-added whenever Bamboo checks the changes, though, which prevents other people from updating/commiting.

fields.description:
The plan is setup to retrieve the module 'comp-test' from CVS.  'comp-test' is setup as an alias module, retrieving 'components' and 'lib'.  This results in the following directory structure:

 $BAMBOO_HOME/data_20/xml-data/build-dir/LW-C2T/comp-test
 $BAMBOO_HOME/data_20/xml-data/build-dir/LW-C2T/comp-test/components
 $BAMBOO_HOME/data_20/xml-data/build-dir/LW-C2T/comp-test/lib

The builder has the 'Working Sub Directory' set to 'components', and runs an ant task.

The 'Specify Custom Results directories' is set to: 'components/all/testData/xml/*.xml' .  In Bamboo 1.2.4 this worked.  In Bamboo 2.0, I need to prepend that by 'comp-test/' in order for it to find the tests.  Not sure which way is right (ie, if it worked because of a bug in Bamboo 1.2.4), but it should somehow be compatible with the Bamboo 1.2.4 data (if by upgrading it because of an upgrade task, or otherwise).

I'm not sure why the malformed data would be written to the logs in the first place... but it's likely that there was a test that wrote malformed data to System.out as part of its testing.  I manually edited out the malformed data from the first buildresults###.xml that failed, but the error happened again on another... so I'm hoping there's a way to fix this without having to manually edit every file.

fields.description:
Bamboo handles test failure reports from Maven2/Surefire incorrectly, this should be easy to reproduce.

For one of my projects, I do a recursive build for a multi-module Maven2 build, lets say the build consists of modules A and B in that order. The actual Maven2 command is "mvn clean install" from the root of the reactor. The following sequence will produce wrong error reports:
1) Bamboo builds module A without errors, B fails with errors. This is reported correctly.
2) A new build of the same reactor starts.
2) Bamboo builds module A, this time with errors. Bamboo now, incorrectly reports errors in both module A and B, even though only tests in module A fail.

Bamboo should  time-stamp the build-start and only include error reports if they are newer than the time-stamp. 

The command "mvn clean install" will handle the reactor recursively, i.e.:
1) Delete all output from module A's target directory (clean).
2) Build module A (install).
3) Delete all output from module B (clean).
4) Build module B (install).

Whereas the functionality that Bamboo supplies should be similar to executing two sequential Maven commands, i.e.:
1) mvn clean (will recursively delete all output from the target directory) and
2) mvn install (builds all modules in the reactor recursively)

The cron triggers are identified by plan keys, if the plan is moved from one project to other or the plan key changes - we don't actually update the Cron jobs in the process.

This means Cron jobs are not triggered for the modified plans.

fields.description:
From forum post: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=23937&tstart=0

Hi,

we are trying to use Bamboo 2.0 Beta 3 together with a Perforce repository. We have set up a remote agent and a build plan accessing the repository but we can't get the agent to synchronize the sources. It invariably fails with the error message

Connect to server failed; check $P4PORT

When you check the log files you see that the agent issues a command of the form

C:/Programs/Perforce/p4.exe workspace -o <client_name>

which causes the error to occur. When you execute the same command manually on the agent machine it works just fine. We tried various workarounds like setting the P4PORT variable either locally in the script that starts the agent or globally in the system environment but to no avail. In principle the Perforce server access data should be transmitted from the Bamboo server (where they are stored in the plan configuration) to the agent but that does not seem to be the case.

Any help in this matter would be greatly appreciated.

Thomas
fields.summary: Perforce failing to connect on agent

fields.description:
{quote}We connect to our repo via URL: svn+ssh://project@server.com/svn/Project
That is, we specify the user in the URL and use an ssh tunnel to identify and set the user on the server side based on the private key. Everyone connects as the same user. The reason for the name in the URL is because in that checkout, there are svn:externals that map a different server and project:
svn+ssh://project2@server2.com/svn/Project2
The problem is that the svn:externals checkout fails because bamboo does not allow the first URL to be input on the config screen, it requires the username to be seperate from the URL. So the initial checkout fails because the svn:externals at Project2 cannot be checked out as the project user, they must be the project2 user. 
{quote}
fields.summary: SVN:Externals should work with SVN+SSH protocol

fields.description:
Firstly, the agent creates logs with different names - for instance if I navigate to my /home/asridhar/Desktop where the agent resides and execute the agent jar it creates an atlassian-bamboo-agent.log file. However if i navigate to /home/asridhar and execute the bamboo agent (located in the desktop folder it) creates atlassian-bamboo.log in /home/asridhar

Secondly, I think users are like to execute the agent from arbitrary directories (i.e. directory where the bamboo-agent doesn't reside), this makes logging a pain! We should create the atlassian-bamboo-agent.log file by default in the Bamboo-Agent-Home directory, regardless of which directory the agent is executed from.

fields.description:
Right now, the requirements can show each requirement being met by at least one agent, but you still have no agents matching ALL the requirements. It's quite a challenge to work out what is needed to be done to get this build to run on any agent. Related to this, we also don't really  know which requirements is causing an agent not to be executable against a plan.

The suggestion is to add a list/matrix down the bottom showing up to 3 agents which are closest to matching the requirements (most matched requirements), and display the requirements which these agents fail on. That way, it's much clearer to the user how to fix the plan/agent so that it can run.
fields.summary: Build Requirement Configuration page should indicate which how agents are not meeting requirements

fields.description:
There seems to be some authentication issues with Perforce repositories.

If I put in a user that does not exist, it correctly returns: "This user is not available on this port (Perforce server)"

If I put in no username, though my current system username exists, it returns: "The perforce user has not been defined"

If I type in a valied perforce username and password, it returns: "Unable to connect to the perforce server, please ensure that your login details are correct"

It appears that it is able to see the server and validate a username, but it won't accept any password whatsoever.

The logfile does not seem to log the command that it is trying to run, either, like Bamboo 1.2.4 so it's difficult to see where the failure happens and what exactly it's trying to do.

Note that we are using an authentication trigger that authenticates against an Active Directory domain. This process works fine in 1.2.4. Extremely verbose log file attached.
fields.summary: Perforce repo still not working on Windows machine

fields.description:
When I try to connect to a database during initial setup I get this error from the web interface:

Could not connect to the database: java.sql.SQLException: Cannot connect to MySQL server on gdcqa:3306. Is there a MySQL server running on the machine/port you are trying to connect to? (java.lang.NumberFormatException)

I've confirmed that I can log in using the user I have attached to this database. I've went so far as to put no password in and it returns the proper 'not authorized' error, so I know that it is attempting to connect.

I've tried various database names and the error is sometimes a little different:

bamboo2
bamboo_2
bamboo_two
bambootwo

I've also tried putting the port number in the connection string as well as leaving it out (standard port 3306.)

Log is attached. Thanks!

fields.description:
For example, try https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CONF

Expression project is undefined on line 8, column 55 in project/viewProject.ftl. The problematic instruction: ---------- ==> ${project.name} [on line 8, column 53 in project/viewProject.ftl] in user-directive ui.header [on line 8, column 1 in project/viewProject.ftl] ---------- Java backtrace for programmers: ---------- f


etc etc etc. Perhaps this should just degrade nicely and say "No project found with that key" or something to that effect
